content:
Hey I was watching some WWDC videos and saw they've announced some interesting features for Swift 5.3 that might be interesting to the people here.

  • Swift can now apparently be used in the same places as C.
  • Multiple trailing closure syntax
  • You can now use pattern matching with catch blocks
  • Added 16 bit floats
  • A new @main attribute that can be put on any function, struct, or class, and act as an entrypoint for the program.
  • Source:
    https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2020/10170/

I also noticed they have a nice dashboard for looking at proposals. https://apple.github.io/swift-evolution/
I know we have we one, I was just saying theirs is nice and itâ€™s interesting what they choose to show.
I was discussing this today with @Josh Triplett. It's also interesting to see that they've centered their process very much on a Discourse instance
see the Swift Evolution section in their list of forums

from what I see, basically there are four categories, and each has its own section:

Announcements - For announcements of Swift evolution proposal reviews and results. All discussion and review of evolution proposals occurs on the swift-evolution mailing list.

Pitches - For proposals for the evolution of Swift including new language features, new standard library APIs, and so on before they enter the review phase. This category will accept email sent to: swift+pitches@forums.swift.org

Proposal Reviews - Posting and commentary on proposals in the review phase. This category will accept email sent to: swift+proposal-reviews@forums.swift.org

Discussion - For general discussion of the evolution of Swift. This category will accept email sent to: swift+evolution-discuss@forums.swift.org

Discourse is certainly an improvement over github in some ways, though it would take a lot of tooling to make up for its deficiencies in tracking compared to github. (It sounds like they've built some of that tooling.)
One interesting observation is that this very much feels like a process that is "auxiliary" to main feature development to me
I could be wrong. But e.g. the requirement to have something implemented etc feels kind of onerous, and I suspect that "core team" development works out differently.
Still, it's a nice description, and I love the "front page" showing the status of things. Muy celoso.
That core team member becomes the review manager for the proposal. The proposal is assigned a proposal number (if it is a new proposal), and then enters the review queue.

this reminds me of the ideas we've kicked around of having things enter a "ready for feedback" period where we highlight certain feature gates and encourage people to read the docs, experiment, etc
